citation.article-title: Paenibacillus sabinae sp. nov., a nitrogen-fixing species isolated from the rhizosphere soils of shrubs.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Paenibacillus sabinae sp. nov.
Paenibacillus sabinae (sa′bi.nae. N.L. gen. n. sabinae of Sabina, referring to the plant Sabina squamata, the source of the rhizosphere soil from which the type strain was isolated).
Cells are Gram-positive, aerobic, motile, straight rods (0.7–0.8×2.7–3.2 μm).
Oval or ellipsoidal endospores are produced, located subterminally or centrally in swollen sporangia.
Colonies on nutrient agar are circular, convex and glossy with entire margins.
The temperature range for growth is 4–37 °C (optimum, 30 °C).
Grows in 3 % (w/v) NaCl, but does not tolerate NaCl at 5 % (w/v).
Voges–Proskauer and methyl red reactions are positive.
Nitrogen fixation is detected by acetylene reduction and from the presence of the nifH gene.

Acid and gas are not produced from the following carbohydrates: glucose, sucrose, lactose, fructose, glycerol, d-xylose, maltose, d-sorbitol, sodium succinate, sodium citrate, glycine and l-aspartate.
Gelatin, casein and starch are not hydrolysed.
The major cellular fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, iso-C16 : 0 and C16 : 0.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 51.9 %.
The type strain, T27T (=CCBAU 10202T=DSM 17841T), was isolated from the rhizosphere soil of Sabina squamata planted in Beijing, China.
